column4: it says "Cannot mount volume." then below "The volume uses the reiser4 file system which is not supported by your system."
I installed reiser4progs and made the partition with Gparted.
have you searched in synaptic for reiser? perhaps it's a package you have to install? or support for it might have been dropped.. the company behind it has had some problems
reiserfs works, but not reiser4..
oh.. I don't really know why... I used reiserfs before but I went back to ext3..
I could use ext4 but it uses almost 2% from my 56GB partition... that is 1GB..
is there anyway to reduce it somehow?
yup.. I know the feeling.. I use xfs on my big drives
not sure.. there are some settings you can change but you'll probably affect performance too..
I formatted my 56GB partition to ext4 and it uses 3.1GB now
should I use xfs instead?

I can't really tell you what will suit you.. I use xfs since it was recommended to me.. it's been working nicely for me so far but I haven't really had any problems with any of the major file systems so far
I need mostly for larger files.. mostly 1GB+
then I think xfs might do nicely... give it a try
I installed xfsprogs and formatted my partition to xfs and it used only 32MB of my 56GB.. so its quite good
It seems I can't add files to it.. says I'm not the owner
try doing a "sudo chown" on the mount point
add -R for recursion
sudo chown -R jadenkorn:jadenkorn /media/MyData/ seemed to work.. thanks
you're welcome
is this "/dev/sda2       /mnt/MyData     xfs     rw,user,auto 0 0" good for autobooting the xfs partition?
looks good to me.. I think you'll find it easier to put it in /media instead of /mnt ... for some reason gnome likes to have the mount points in /media
